column195: I am currently developing an open textbook in (and for) the course Ling 611 - Applied phonology, with four graduate students. Thusfar, this semester we have worked through the general structure of the book and should have reasonable drafts of 4 chapters (out of a potential 10 or 12) by the end of this semester. The book will be developed further in the next offering of Ling 611 this summer by 6~8 more students. The current content will serve as a point of departure that the new students review to  get an overview of the course area. They are then are given responsibilities for some further development of the core main chapters and then each produces an applied chapter focusing the framework of the book on a distinct learner population that they, themselves, have personal experience with. In Fall 2018 there will be one student doing the course as a directed study who will follow the same general process. After the fourth iteration of the course,  in Spring 2019, with 8~10 students, it may well be ready to go public in some limited form. We have about half a dozen content experts from other institutions who will be providing feedback initially to the students and then later, hopefully, they and their students will contribute unique content as well.
column208: At this point in the semester, with about three weeks to go, all 4 students seem very enthusiastic about what they have learned and the quality of the research that they have done. Their outlines of the chapters look promising. We had the usual family emergencies, crashed computers and broken bones to contend with, along with just the evolution of the course as it emerged. It looks pretty good at the top level now and the overall conceptual framework seems solid. Will see how we land by the end of April. By the end of the summer, the 4 core chapters should be approaching textbook content and format so that we may be able to actually use them in Spring 2019 in place of about 50% of the currently required textbook "load!"

column195: The difficulty with finding samples for inclusion in class: published authors of narrative nonfiction and essays tend to retain subsidiary rights after first publication in a magazine or journal. Freelance pay rates are bad enough, but no one wants to lose potential income streams by entering all one's works into creative commons. Royalties are important to creative writers. Until such time as OER or CC options can plug that gap, I'll ask my students to purchase anthologies.
column208: I have no evidence to support anything other than a neutral response to this set of questions. For the kind of teaching I do and the reading I expect of students, I can't see causation in these cases.

column195: Although I haven't used OER, these are my predictions.
column208: I am thinking mainly of textbooks in my answers, and I don't think an open textbook would engage students any more than a printed text that they pay for. However, students actively involved in a creating a resource would be able to experiment with new ways of learning, generate enthusiasm, and express their diverse needs. I tend to have more "traditional" students who like print books and the way that we engage with literary texts in the classroom (which are often low-tech options). I am not certain that OED would affect their participation/engagement, which is already significant.

column195: When I search for a viable well-done textbook, I have many many options at my fingertips and am able to find resources that I feel fully confident and enthusiastic about.  OER has little to offer me and my classes, and although this could change in the future as the options grow, but this would take time (possibly quite a bit of time).
column208: Students often express frustration as to the amount of online activities, readings, services they need to participate in.  They express appreciation for experiential work in the classrooms that fully engages them in their learning.

column195: At best, I find that the OER materials available in my primary discipline are simplistic and incomplete.  Occasionally I do have students who need rudimentary review.  These are the ones that I refer to the limited suitable materials that I have found.
column208: Evidence to support any of my feelings on this engagement would be hard to substantiate.  Mostly, I find that despite repeated referrals to this additional material - many students simply choose not to engage with the recommended OER material.  As a result, those most needing the support that could be found in these resources often find themselves falling further behind.

column208: My experience with students is that they interact better with printed textbooks than with online resources. I post podcasts and videos on Moodle that students never watch. But if they read and highlight/write in textbooks, they tend to remember them better. I am reluctant to move to a completely online format as I am concerned that students will not have any retention.
